summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio, primarily dated May-June 2021, alleging widespread SEC corruption and ongoing securities fraud. The author details specific cases involving companies like Riot Blockchain (RIOT), Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE), and various penny stock shells, accusing the SEC of obstruction, failing to investigate, and facilitating money laundering and market manipulation.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the emails, alleging massive SEC corruption and securities fraud related to multiple companies and individuals. He identifies himself as a whistleblower whose tips have been ignored or obstructed.

persons.name: Chad Everett Harris
persons.context: Mentioned as supervising the construction of a data center in Rockdale, Texas for Whinstone, which was bought by Northern Data.

persons.name: Mathis Schultz
persons.role: Former Private Banker, Founder of Northern Data
persons.context: Founder of Northern Data in 2015, mentioned in the context of the company's history.

persons.name: Dougie Cifu
persons.context: Repeatedly accused of knowingly lying about Virtu/NITE's equity market making share volumes during a May 2021 earnings call to conceal illegal activity.

persons.name: Alex Kramm
persons.context: Mentioned as having an exchange with Dougie Cifu on the earnings call; the author challenges him to explain Cifu's lack of transparency.

persons.name: Dan Fannon
persons.context: Addressed by Dougie Cifu during the May 2021 earnings call regarding share volumes.

persons.name: Ms. Pasquinelli
persons.context: Addressed in an email regarding SEC actions that qualify for whistleblower awards but have not been posted, alleging SEC obstruction.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named in a 2019 SEC action for microcap stock fraud; the author claims the case was based on his information.

persons.name: John M. Fife
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in 2020 for dealing billions of penny stock shares without registration; the author claims the case was based on his information.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.role: Accused Unregistered Penny Stock Dealer (JMJ Financial)
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in 2020 for operating as an unregistered dealer; the author claims the case was based on his information.

persons.name: Mr. Gottschall
persons.context: Repeatedly accused of gross corruption and conducting a sham investigation into Riot Blockchain (RIOT) without visiting its alleged headquarters.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Addressed in an email, implored to send a subpoena to the author to expose SEC fraud regarding Riot Blockchain.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Described as a central figure in multiple alleged money laundering shells, including MGT Capital, Inergetics, and Riot Blockchain.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Mentioned as having paid to resolve False Claims Act allegations and later becoming a large shareholder in Millennium Biotech/Inergetics, which was controlled by Barry Honig.

persons.name: Chad Readler
persons.context: Identified as the prosecutor on the Brian Colleran civil case; later made a federal judge by President Trump.

persons.name: Mark B. Fisher
persons.role: Owner of MBF Clearing and MBF Capital
persons.context: Mentioned in connection with Riot Blockchain's acquisition of a trading platform; his entities are based in New York, raising questions about a "Miami" connection.

persons.name: Eric Bustilloe
persons.context: Described as a "grossly corrupt Piece of Shit" on par with Gottschall, potentially connected to the Miami aspect of the Mark Fisher inquiry.

persons.name: Dmitry Akhanov
persons.role: CEO of Rusnano USA, Russian Federal Energy Agency Official
persons.context: Identified as an insider in Bioptix (predecessor to RIOT) and a board member of NeoPhotonics, raising national security concerns about Russian involvement.

persons.name: Judge Cote
persons.context: Accused of a gross miscarriage of justice in sentencing Dan Kamensky, allegedly because Kamensky interfered with a deal involving Handler/Ressler.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: His sentencing by Judge Cote is described as a miscarriage of justice, set up by Handler/Ressler because he interfered with their deal.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Implied to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC; allegedly set up Dan Kamensky for interfering with a deal involving Ares Management.

persons.name: Ressler
persons.role: Likely a financier (co-founder of Ares Management)
persons.context: Implied to be connected to Handler from Drexel; his firm Ares Management was allegedly harmed by Kamensky's actions, leading to the setup.

persons.name: Mr. Searles
persons.context: Accused, along with Banerjee, of protecting UBS San Diego and leaving multiple frauds up and running in the LA area.

persons.name: Banerjee
persons.context: Accused, along with Searles, of protecting UBS San Diego and leaving multiple frauds up and running in the LA area.

persons.name: Jason Sunstein
persons.role: CFO of multiple OTC Pink shell companies
persons.context: San Diego resident identified as CFO of several alleged money laundering shells like Viper Networks, known to SEC LA officials.

persons.name: Ashraf Rofail
persons.role: CEO of Santeon Group/International Land Alliance
persons.context: CEO of companies involved in alleged Mexico vacation property investments using stock as currency.

connections.description: Dilorio is addressing Pasquinelli (SEC OWB) with allegations that the SEC is obstructing whistleblower awards for cases based on his information.
Dilorio repeatedly and directly accuses Gottschall (SEC Denver) of corruption and conducting a sham investigation into Riot Blockchain.
Both are implicated in multiple alleged money laundering shell companies; Sason's entities held shares in Honig-controlled Inergetics.
Colleran became a large shareholder in Millennium Biotech/Inergetics, a company controlled by Honig, after a fraudulent purchase agreement.
Cifu interacted with analyst Kramm on a Virtu Financial earnings call regarding share volume disclosures.
Implied to have a professional history from Drexel and to be involved in the Neiman Marcus deal that Dan Kamensky interfered with.
Both are SEC LA officials accused by Dilorio of jointly protecting UBS San Diego and facilitating ongoing frauds.
Akhanov was an insider in Bioptix, a company that Honig/Stetson invested in, which later became Riot Blockchain.

events.title: Virtu Financial Q1 2021 Earnings Call
events.description: Virtu CEO Dougie Cifu states that April equity market making volumes were "a hair under 10 billion shares per day," which the author alleges is a blatant lie to conceal massive illegal naked shorting and OTCM money laundering volumes.

events.title: SEC Ends Investigation of Riot Blockchain
events.description: SEC official Mr. Gottschall sends a letter to Riot Blockchain stating the investigation is over and no enforcement action is recommended. The author claims this was a sham investigation as Gottschall never visited the company's alleged headquarters.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al. in Microcap Fraud
events.description: The SEC files charges against Joshua Sason and others in an elaborate microcap stock fraud. The author claims this action was based on his whistleblower information.

events.title: SEC Charges John M. Fife for Unregistered Dealing
events.description: The SEC charges John M. Fife and companies he controls for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer. The author claims this action was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener (JMJ Financial)
events.description: The SEC charges Justin W. Keener for operating as an unregistered penny stock dealer. The author claims this action was based on his information.

events.title: Northern Data Sells Whinstone Texas Data Center
events.description: Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin sells the Whinstone Texas data center, which was being built under Chad Everett Harris's supervision.

keyFacts: The author, Christopher J. Dilorio, alleges the SEC is engaged in systematic criminal obstruction and corruption, actively facilitating ongoing securities fraud and money laundering while denying him whistleblower awards.

Riot Blockchain (RIOT) is alleged to be a Honig/Stetson money laundering shell that only exists in SEC filings, with its Castle Rock, CO headquarters being a front co-located with an ISP and a Pakistani BPO company.

Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE) CEO Dougie Cifu is accused of knowingly lying about share volumes to conceal that the company's core business is illegal naked shorting of OTC markets (OTCM) shells to facilitate money laundering.
Russian official Dmitry Akhanov (CEO of Rusnano USA) is identified as an insider in Bioptix, the predecessor to Riot Blockchain, raising alleged national security concerns.

The author claims multiple successful SEC enforcement actions (Sason, Fife, Keener) were based on his whistleblower tips but were never posted as award-eligible by the SEC Office of the Whistleblower, constituting obstruction.
